"the Farsighted" | titles=[[King of Númenor]] | position= | location=[[Númenor]] | affiliation=The [[Faithful]] | language=[[Adûnaic]], [[Quenya]] and [[Sindarin]] | birth={{SA|3035}} | birthlocation= | rule={{SA|3177}} - {{SA|3255}} (78 years) | death={{SA|3255}} | deathlocation= | age=220 | notablefor= | house=[[House of Elros]] | parentage=[[Ar-Gimilzôr]] and [[Inzilbêth]]{{UT|Kings}}, entry XXIII ''Ar-Gimilzôr (Tar-Telemnar)'' | siblings=[[Gimilkhâd]] | spouse= | children=[[Tar-Míriel|Míriel]] | gender=Male | height= | hair= | eyes= | clothing= | weapons= | steed= }} '''Tar-Palantir''' was the twenty-fourth [[King of Númenor]], who tried to restore the [[Númenor|Númenórean]] traditions during the last dark years of the realm. ==History== Tar-Palantir received the [[Adûnaic]] name ''Inziladûn'' from his father after his birth.{{UT|Kings}}, entry XXIV ''Tar-Palantir (Ar-Inziladûn)'' His father [[Ar-Gimilzôr]] was a bitter opponent of the [[Valar]] and the [[Elves]], and had banished the speaking of the [[Elvish|Elven tongues]] in his realm. However, Inziladûn's mother, [[Inzilbêth]], was secretly a member of the [[Faithful]] and taught her son to be an [[Elf-friend]]. When Inziladûn took the [[Sceptre of Númenor]] it was a time of great darkness in [[Númenor]]. Ever since the time of [[Tar-Atanamir]], every King had spoken against the Valar and questioned the [[Ban of the Valar|Ban]] they had put upon the [[Númenóreans]] against sailing into the [[Aman|West]]. By this time, the Númenóreans's riches and power grew, but also did their fear for Death, and their joy and years lessened.{{S|Akallabeth}} Inziladûn sought to repent of these actions of his predecessors and took a royal name in the Elvish tongue [[Quenya]] in the tradition of his ancestors: Tar-Palantir. As a consequence, he let the Faithful live in peace. Once again the [[Nimloth of Númenor|White Tree]] was properly tended, for Tar-Palantir's gift of foresight allowed him to ascertain that if the White Tree perished, then the line of Kings would also come to an end. The King also faithfully observed the ancient [[Three Prayers|religious ceremonies]] of the Númenóreans at due times. The Valar did not respond to Tar-Palantir's repentance because of the insolence of the Kings before him, and because the greater part of the Númenóreans were still hostile to the [[Valar|Lords of the West]]. Nor did Elven ships ever come from [[Tol Eressëa]] to Númenor again. Tar-Palantir became filled with sorrow over the continuing rebellion of his people, and began to spend more of his time at the tower of [[Tar-Minastir]] in the west of the isle, looking to the West with nostalgia, maybe hoping to see a ship from there. But even the sight of it was withheld from him. His brother Gimilkhâd followed the policies of his father Ar-Gimilzôr and became the leader of the party that had been called the [[King's Men]] and opposed the will of Tar-Palantir both openly and in secret. After the death of Gimilkhâd, his son [[Ar-Pharazôn|Pharazôn]] probably became the leader of the King's Men, because he was even more restless and eager for power and wealth than his father and used his renown as a captain both by land and sea and his great wealth to turn the hearts of the people to him. As a consequence, there was strife and rebellion in Númenor during the reign of Tar-Palantir.{{App|Numenor}} Tar-Palantir married late and had only one child, a daughter named [[Tar-Míriel|Míriel]]. According to the [[Law of Succession in Númenor|law of succession]], Míriel would have succeeded her father as [[Queen of Númenor]] with the royal name Tar-Míriel. However, when Tar-Palantir died, Pharazôn, the leader of the rebellion, married Míriel against her will and against the laws of Númenor, because she was his first cousin, usurped the sceptre and took the title Ar-Pharazôn (Tar-Calion). His wife Míriel was named Ar-Zimraphel. ==Etymology== ''Palantir'' is a [[Quenya]] name. It means "Farsighted"{{App|Numenor}}, paragraph after ''These are the names of the Kings and Queens of Númenor:'' or "He who looks afar".{{UT|Index}}, entry ''Tar-Palantir'' It is a compound of ''palan'' ("far") and a form of ''tir-'' ("to watch").{{webcite|author=Paul Strack|articleurl=https://www.eldamo.org/content/words/word-925210673.html|articlename=Q. ''Palantir'' m.|website=[http://eldamo.org/index.html Eldamo - An Elvish Lexicon]|accessed=13 January 2022}} Like for all the rulers of Númenor whose name was inscribed in the Scroll of Kings, the prefix ''tar-'' ("high") was added to his name.{{UT|Kings}}, first paragraph and entry I to XXV ==Other names== Inziladûn is the name given to Tar-Palantir at birth by his father. It is [[Adûnaic]] for "Flower of the West".{{UT|Index}}, entry ''*Númellótë''{{UT|5a}}, note 13 It is a compound of ''inzil'' ("flower") and ''adûn'' ("west").{{webcite|author=Paul Strack|articleurl=https://www.eldamo.org/content/words/word-4129002177.html|articlename=Ad. ''Inziladûn'' m.|website=[http://eldamo.org/index.html Eldamo - An Elvish Lexicon]|accessed=13 January 2022}} The meaning of the Adûnaic prefix ''Ar-'' is not glossed, but Paul Strack suggests it means "king" and is a prefixal form of ''ârû'' ("king") or derived from the same root.{{webcite|author=Paul Strack|articleurl=https://www.eldamo.org/content/words/word-3166554081.html|articlename=Ad.
